review_title: Exciting industry, Great Company, Awesome Team!
pros:
PayPal over the years has been on a trajectory growth and in no better times than now to have visionary leader Dan Schulman lead an awesome team towards lots of untapped opportunities in the fintech space. This is definitely more significant post the spilt from eBay Inc where opportunities to partner and acquisitions of high potential companies helps PayPal 

The organization is definitely fast moving and in this organization, things move pretty fast. Keeping up to the pace and the changes can be both exciting and challenging. 

Great teamwork and sharing happening across the organization. Understanding the importance of keeping ourselves as one team, PayPal has a great work culture where sharing is very core and key to keep abreast of our fast changing environment, 

Keeping it real - management team never fails to keep it real for all our employees, not masking any bad news but for all of us to have the courage to face brutal facts and action on necessary to keep us in a good shape. 

Culture - Collaboration is key cornerstone to how we work together as a team , One Team! And we're constantly reminded of how vulnerable us as an organization can be if we don't continue to innovate and be at the forth front of offering the best to our customer with customer centricity at the core of our business.
cons: No time to lament on missed boat/opportunities, thus it can be pretty much of a culture shock for those who are not used to the pace of this organization and the constant changes to meet the needs of our customers

review_title: A great company and workplace, but with lots of room for improvement
pros:
1. Good benefits. As far as software engineer positions are concerned, it beats most of the Singapore-based company (foreign banks excluded) I know of.
2. The company makes a genuine efforts to upgrade the technical skills of the employees.
3. The team dynamics are wonderful, and there are many great technical talents.
4. Work-life balance is great, although mileage varies wildly from group to group.
cons:
1. There tend to be organizational restructure once every one year or so, essentially the same employees and managers being reshuffled into different groups/organizations. It can be a real distraction overall.
2. The code base is largely ancient and with varying quality. Although there has been company-wide efforts for migration and cleanup, there is still a long way to go.
3. The quality of the middle managers (senior managers, director levels) varies a lot. Some are really soul-less, who simply take the order from above without much consideration of nuturing the people, or really care about what customer need.
4. Domain solos. This is observed between different technology groups. There are cases in which domain ownership (or lack of) takes precedence over sound architectural considerations

review_title: It Is Not What You Know, It Is Who You Know Here
pros: All the great things the above mentioned are true such as free soda, candies, fruits, and Thursday breakfast (that’s about it).
cons: What a mess!  No direction, politic is so thick that one can cut through it with a knife.  Single product company and nothing new has been invented for years.  It is just a payment gateway company which aggregates all the payment options out there, so I am not sure how long it will survive in the marketplace.  This company has so many heads from Marketing Head to Head of Merchant Services, but not sure what they do.  A bunch of snake politicians who prefer to talk than do.  Heard of a Massive Exodus in March 2011.  I am sure to jump on the bandwagon.  Do not come to PayPal Singapore, there are more suitable/better places to work out there.  I am so disappointed that I made the move to join this place.

review_title: Good work culture, Good Compensation, A bit lacking in terms of adoption of new technologies but working hard to improve
pros:
1) Good Compensation. >50% increment over my previous job.
2) Good perks ( Buffet lunches & Breakfast, $1000 flexible benefits, excellent healthcare that covers specialist visits and child birth)
3) Lots of team outings, meals and parties paid for by the company.
4) Lots of smart people who are diligent with their job.
5) Company is doing very well and this is a morale booster
6) Highly disciplined workforce who care about their job and are willing to work the extra mile should the situation arises.
7) Willing to spend money to invest in new technologies and training for staff
cons:
1) Work hours can be very long during critical periods.
2) Some of the technologies and tools are out of date. Management recognises this and has been investing a lot of money in trying to improve this area.
3) Big company politics and bureaucracy.
4) Very process-driven company

review_title: APAC Internal Audit - hire and fire culture
pros:
Benefits and welfare good
Every Tuesday free lunch 
Dental can cover spouse using dental card
cons:
1. Hire and fire culture - 4 unfair dismissal in a short period of 2 years, resulting low morale within the team.
2. Constant change of APAC leadership - lack of stability and no clear direction
3. Promotion is not by merit - staff got promoted 3 times in less than 2 years without valid justifications and results from management.
4. High turnover due to poor hiring - APAC has been hiring auditors who doesn’t have relevant experience and competency. The mismatch of skillset has caused the misfit to the company, which results in “hire and fire” culture.

Last word - avoid to join the APAC internal audit unless you are prepare to lose your job in the near future.  The fear of “don’t know” when might be your last day is just too much risk to take.

review_title: Best Place to Work in SG
pros:
I started working from contractor until I got converted to full-time employee. I've had experience working for several companies in SG, so I know which company treats their employee badly and which company take care their employee. Suffice to say, in my opinion, PayPal is one of the best employers in SG. There are several reviews here in glassdoor that said about office politic and all. I can only say that office politics are everywhere regardless of company we just need to know how to handle it (read a lot of career/professional website if you are clueless)

- Excellent work life balance (working from home, etc), if not one of the best in SG that promotes this.
- Great salary and benefits.
- Exposure to latest technology and fintech industry leader.
cons:
- At times, overengineering design and solution. It's better to think design and solution that are simple yet extensible rather than thinking on how to come up with a silver bullet solution. That silver bullet might be useless when facing against the change on requirements.
- It's a big and distributed company, so expect overhead in their process.
- Legacy codes are terrible (because of the way previous engineers wrote it not because of language), which causing a misconception and argument on C++ vs Java. Both languages are good if being used properly and both can be terrible if they aren't written properly.
- It can be harsh at times during restructuring period.
- Blaming culture is everywhere (esp, across departments), you must know how to cover your back. Issue or failure will always be there. Rather than point the finger at someone, it's better to deal with the issues and learn from it. After all, you are trying to achieve the same goal.

review_title: In a midst of a Reorganization & Business transformation - Growing Pangs
pros:
- Good culture on diversity inclusion  and living company values and demonstrated by CEO
- Strong focus on Risk, Security and Compliance. About 30% of staff is hired to perform such roles.
- Work/Life Balance : PayPal gives a 1 month sabbatical for every 5 years of service
- Nice office environment and depending on location free lunch and ample stock of a variety of drinks and beverages
- PayPal brand well recognized in core markets like USA, Europe and Cross border commerce markets in APAC. 
- Cash rick company that invests in fintech startups and acquisitions over the last decade. Acquisitions include: iZettle, Simility, Hyperwallet and Braintree.
cons:
- Business reorganization in process. Workforce reduction due to redundancies or change in org structure led to people leaving the company due to attrition or redundancy.
- Marketing teams from various products were merged with the new CMO joining PayPal. 
- This followed with Worldwide Sales team reorg where PayPal sales team have been merged with Braintree sales team for Mid and Large enterprise business. This started in USA last year and have been expanded this year to the International markets. This has caused lots of uncertainty to employees
- Product strategy is to have a single PayPal platform with other services like Braintree, iZettle, Hyperwallet, Simility as part of the platform. The various product team have been merged back to the PayPal product team group. Integration is still in progress and question is whether products like Braintree  will still exist post integration.
- Investment by the company is on the top clients in the USA, less focus on growing the international markets. The competition like Adyen and Stripe are heavily investing in other international markets via increase local acquiring and local/regional payment methods. This will make PayPal less competitive in meeting merchant needs internationally and drive merchants to other providers.
- Underwriting and Pricing teams sits in the USA and have no local context of the business to work with Sales to price deals to win the merchant.
- Management is telling employees that the strategy is clear and the right thing to do but have no definite details to share on the execution  especially on the people front. People are concerned where they will be any impact in their roles with this transformation.

pros: Great place to work; free soda machines, bagels, great breakrooms stuffed with supplies much better than 7-eleven. Perks that pampered employees.

We are seeing ex-bankers taking up top jobs creating their own empires, behaving like warlords killing off team members that are not on their side. Fighting eBay internally is secondary objective.

review_title: Core principles are for show off
pros: **Used** to be a very good company. Work life balance decent.
cons:
1. New hires get more salary even with lower experience.
 2. Lot of re-orgs hamper your growth. 
3. Rules are on paper and managers or directors apply rules according to their own choice - be it for promotion or project assignments. 
4. Fire culture. Not given prior info to improve performance, rather people get fired at whim of management. 
5. As lot of management folks hired from outside over last 4-5 years, the culture has gone for a toss because of them carrying their bad legacy from past companies. 
6. Referrals - lot of nepotism, lack of transparency and fake rejection points. Because the managers and directors all want to earn referral bonus. My experience - candidates with very good interviews rejected without reasonable explanation, referrals not getting the calls most of the times, but if you apply in LinkedIn directly, you get the call for same job. 
7. Managers don't help in your career growth. Either you become politically active to know what projects you should take or you are doomed. 
8. Promotions very tough for existing employees. If you have other company offer letter, you get promo easily at cost of other loyal employees who did not give interviews outside. 
9. Core principles - only INCLUSION is what is trending around the world matters here now. 
10. Not uniformly judgement to all. 
11. Even Directors bar a few have biased views and dont think about people working under them. Selfish.

pros: Pay and other perks are good. However the downside doesn't give mental peace.
cons: Company culture is good but it is not exercised in the GCS unit. When you see other business units operate differently from yours it pinches. I've noticed this only in India unit. The standards they set are not reasonable and they push you to achieve it. I hope this Indian center in GCS is managed by leaders abroad who implement the 4 pillars or PayPal in their duties performed.

pros: Nothing notable. I'd say the salad bar was decent at office but I dont really miss it. Despite the cons below, I'd still recommend the company because not all teams are alike. If you are lucky, you might end up in a good org with a good team.
cons: 1. Was typecast into a maintenance project/working on a legacy code base. Because of parental leaves, couldnt look for jobs outside. Despite expressing need for more challenging work for 2 years, NOTHING was done. 2. WLB - imbalanced on-call support. I was made to be the primary on-call guy for supporting a legacy app that was prone to frequent crashes. Not given cycles to improve its tech stack/performance, just to keep supporting it till its deprecation. 3. Because of above, no room for personal career growth/skillset upgrade. 4. Bad/basic parental policy. The managers treat you like you are going on a vacation if you take parental leave. 5. Disgruntled old time employees who liked being knowledge silos and hated sharing their knowledge unless coddled/getting manager involved.

review_title: Great company to work for overall
job_title: MTS1 Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Collaborative culture: PayPal values teamwork and collaboration across all levels of the organization. Opportunities for career advancement: PayPal offers training programs and leadership development opportunities for career growth. I loved it Work-life balance: PayPal offers flexible working arrangements and encourages employees to prioritize their well-being. Flexible hybrid working remotely and from the office. Competitive benefits: PayPal offers comprehensive benefits packages, including health insurance, 401(k) matching, and employee discounts.
cons: - Too many reorgs, in my opinion; they keep changing and switching teams more often than other companies, an average of once a year. - Although all teams try to adopt the culture and working ethics, sometimes you may come across teams that do not follow them. They are very rare, but they do exist. - in some teams, the promotion opportunity has a high bar, and other teams don't depend on the team.

pros: PayPal offers a lot of flexibility, good benefits, and (for the most part) hires talented and kind people. They provide fantastic resources (new Mac book pros, ultra wide monitors, etc), value work-life balance (team and manager dependent), and understand the benefits of remote work.
cons: This company doesn't value it's employees when push comes to shove. The layoffs were handled terribly and opaquely. They followed this up by not providing raises to workers after boasting across-the-board profits at the quarterly earnings call a week prior. There is no clear path for career growth either, since workers are expected to "solve big problems" to get noticed (which, of course, incentivizes constant big problems). The rush to push new features causes many of these problems, so little to no time is ever assigned to remove mounting tech debt.

job_title: Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Used to have amazing benefits and culture. You will learn everything related to fintech if you work here. Remote work is nice.
cons:
They do not care. The only thing they remotely care about is making sure the CEO's pockets are well-lined. PayPal is one of the worst managed companies I have ever worked for. Leadership treats the company like a child treats a Tamagotchi and get just as confused as a baby when it dies it front of them. They slashed benefits every year, rewarded the lowest performers on every team, kept all departments in the dark about each other's goals, and lied to the employee's faces multiple times about layoffs. Unprofessional doesn't even begin to cover it. 

PayPal and its affiliates talk a big game about Diversity and Inclusion, but it's all lip service. Every time a person of color left the company they'd publish an open letter about how badly they were treated or how little they were paid compared to caucasian employees. These allegations were never addressed by management. Management will never acknowledge ANYTHING, be it suspicious business practices that make the news, how much loss the company experiences, whether your position is on the line or not, or how they pay everyone well below industry standards. If you brought a problem to light, or requested to be treated like a human being and not a number or a punching bag, leadership would act like YOU were the cause of the problem. Honestly, being treated as just a number would have been better than how we were actually treated.

review_title: Cons are really Pros in disguise
pros: I will list the pros, then the cons. It may seem counterintuitive or unconventional, but if you can properly approach and overcome the cons, then they will be pros. PROS: It's a good company to work for if you are coming in with a high salary if you are able to negotiate near or beyond the max of the range. I negotiated near the top of the range and the range got lower after I joined. The total compensation package should be considered beyond just the base salary because there are ways to double your compensation (or better), even though it is a publicly traded company now, not still a unicorn startup. These non-base-salary components of the compensation package require that the company's stock (PYPL) price does well, but if you are a key player at the company you can help the company to do well with it's stock performance as long as the market conditions are favorable. If you like to learn new things or you are new to the field/industry, this is a good company to stay with long term. You will have access to long term benefits like sabbaticals. Lots of people are getting paid well for not working, based on their years of contributions. As with any company there are layoffs. Regardless of whatever the criteria is that these layoffs are based on, layoffs at this company are not a con if you compare to other companies. If you get laid off, as with other major companies in this industry, you can negotiate or maybe even be offered initially a decent severance package when you exit (again, getting paid for not working based on your contributions during your tenure is another positive aspect of working at the company because they try to value your dedication even if you get laid off). If you are the type of person who anticipates cost cutting and quits before the layoffs come then it's a non issue other than your own strategy precluding you from severance enjoyed by thousands of other employees. You may have seen some high profile technology companies with extremely generous severances which are maybe 2-3x more than what you get here, but it’s still better than most companies if you look at all industries. The company culture is strongly LGBTQ+ friendly and the company will celebrate your gender transition. Obviously if you don't identify this way you can still fit in just fine. You will work with a diverse group of people from all walks of life and the company will promote inclusion and protect a diverse culture. This is an opportunity to learn about other cultures and go to other countries where you may even learn a new language. The company gives to those in need and has a strong impact, achieving the vision of democratizing finance for those who need it most. There are charity programs in the organization which facilitate donation matching to give to charities and non-profits which are approved and you can submit charities to be added. The company facilitated a huge amount of government payment to people who needed money for Covid. The company provided relief for people in Turkey who suffered the earthquake. You will have opportunities to choose to speak in front of many people at the company on many different topics from business to technology and social issues that the company’s impact can improve. Work hard every day, keep an open mind, and you can really make a positive impact here. You can move around to different teams in order to gain more experiences without having to fully off-board and onboard. This is a good way to build a network of managers and others who will vouch for you. Last but not least, I am giving the highest number of stars for the CEO Dan Schulman who in my view has upheld a strong sense of social responsibility and he had a strong sensitivity to social issues. Dan could make you feel like you were really making a difference and I believe I was. Dan’s leadership promoted one-team behaviors (collaboration instead of blame-games). Dan’s leadership facilitated and strongly drove a very strong sense of customer championship. Arguably the customer is the number one stakeholder. Take care of the customer and almost everything else will fall into place for the rest of the stakeholders (investors, stockholders, employees). I wish Dan well in his retirement which he announced would be at the end of 2023. I believe that Dan's vision and legacy will live on because he is a sensitive, hard working, impact focused CEO. Sorry if you didn’t get a chance to work under Dan before he retires.
cons: CONS: The cons are basically how the pros could affect you depending who you are and how you conduct yourself, so arguably there are no cons (hence 5 star rating). Even though I performed well enough to receive bonuses, awards, and even raises: base salary raises and cost of living adjustments together did not keep base salary in step with inflation over the years according to any inflation calculator. Base salary gradually slipped tens of thousands of dollars behind inflation. This is actually common with most companies. If you negotiated a salary in the 90th% or better you may be able to make up for it as long as the company stock price is on an incline and you take full advantage of ESPP, RSUs, perf stock, get other awards and bonuses, then base salary falling significantly behind inflation is not a con as long as you can still negotiate toward the top of the range. I can’t complain about this because when stock prices were skyrocketing my total compensation one single year “compensated” for the other years. Go to work for a company you are invested in or else you are wasting time including your own. I invested my time, energy, significant amount of my base salary into the company and I was rewarded. Depending on your timing, level coming in, rank advancement or lack thereof, who you are dealing with, and your negotiation skills moving in and out of the company your mileage may vary. Managers and other senior staff leaving the company caused a lot of shuffling. It’s worth mentioning that even the CEO is leaving. If you find remediating these inefficiencies to be emotionally or cognitively daunting it may be a problem for your velocity, but not an issue as long as you can discipline yourself to push through the daunting work or alternatively see it as a time to move on. This is not the only company effected by senior people leaving, so you should weigh it relative to other companies you are considering. Depending on your grit and capability to focus, and exit strategy, your mileage may vary. Job security might not be a thing you get from within the company if you come into it with a high salary relative to your peers ranking similarly in the company, but since staying long term resulted in my base salary getting tens of thousands of dollars behind inflation I was better off getting my job security from managers and peers who vouch for my performance to my next employer. If you are a top performer who demands to be paid like one you might not stick around for your sabbatical or other long term benefits even if you perform and intend to stay that long. If you are considering this as an opportunity to learn and grow your experience rather than meet expectations and be paid like a top performer then this is probably not an issue and you may in fact have some job security at the company since some have been at the company for over a decade. As a full time, permanent member of staff who recognizes that I am not a permanent fixture at the company there was some distraction and pieces to pick up after surviving layoffs until 2023, but again for those primarily learning and looking for experience this may be an opportunity to wear some hats left behind by top paid performers and non-performers who were let go in group reductions of force. My managers never reprimanding me and even giving me awards and performance recognitions perhaps should have but did not exempt me from the reduction of force criteria. Depending how much your job security strategy depends on remaining employed for relatively longer terms by a single company, your mileage may vary. Another complaint I heard from peers which wasn't a problem for me but the company has strict security policies which some staff think makes them produce output more slowly, but this is more efficient than other companies with similar regulatory and security requirements. If you are only concerned with your ability to have high velocity output you should be taking laxatives and spending the day drinking water sitting on the toilet instead of working at a company handling people’s money. I don’t believe this to be a paypal specific problem, but rather a finance-tech problem where there is an inherent culture conflict between high velocity innovation culture and security requirements. Some say security is inversely proportional to convenience, but you can and should overcome this for the sake of the customer. Innovation and at least secure operations are in fact what the customer deserves. If you are a customer champion, then this is a challenge you may be rewarded for overcoming. Depending how well you negotiate fact-of-life type friction in your workflow, your mileage may vary. Maybe not a con for everyone but for some people who don't like commuting, you may be required to come into the office regularly or semi-regularly even though for most individual contributors commuting shaves off significant time from your productive workday. You will be required to collaborate remotely with people all over its global presence regardless of whether your online meeting is coming from home or the office. You may also be expected to pivot hours to be available for global collaborations, which isn’t a bad thing as long as you don’t also have to commute. Your mileage may vary depending on your situation (such as your manager, location policies). You have control over this when you decide whether or not you want to join the company, but if you are moved by middle management to a different team under a different manager, the expectations may change. Your mileage may (literally) vary.

review_title: A Potentially Interesting Place to Work At Marred by Senior Leadership Issues
pros: As someone who likes fintech, working for one of the big players in the industry is great. Working on code that deals with large amounts of money movement is very fulfilling. Good work life balance. Respectable perks.
cons: The number of reorgs, like many other reviews posted, is not an understatement. The company is stuck in an endless cycle of reorgs where orgs are split, then merged, then split again, and so forth. To make matters worse, many of these reorgs come with layoffs. It is one of the most unstable companies I've worked for. Come springtime, everyone braced for layoffs. However, now it is year round. Worst of all, the reorgs have not achieved any actual perceivable positive effects in the company for employees. In fact, we often have to pick up the responsibilities left by the teams that were cut. This hints that senior leadership does not know where to take the company, and then they leave; the number of leadership change emails is absurd. The number of contractors is astounding and significantly outnumber full-timers in many teams. Part of it was the company trying to ride the pandemic wave. PayPal does not hide the fact that it will offshore jobs if there is an opportunity.

pros: Your leader's goal is to make sure you succeed and they meet with you once a week to check in and make sure you're going in a positive direction You meet with your colleagues twice per week to catch up on changes, problems, and sometimes you just have fun bonding They encourage and support diversity Lots of amazing health and wellness benefits Sabbatical (guaranteed paid vacation) at 5 years Maternity, Bonding, Short term, and Long term leave Mostly flexible with FMLA/Disability needs Shift differentials for evenings and weekends Paid Holidays Wellness Days (automatic day off once per quarter that is available outside of PTO/Sick time)
cons: You deal with employees who are calling you for help and sometimes that can be annoying. Not because it's their fault they didn't get trained but because they often feel the need to "know more" than they do and lie to you about what they did and didn't do to resolve the issue. This can lead to a lot of running around in circles and wasting time until you figure out the original EASY solution was never taken as the employee lied about trying that already. There are inconsistencies too often that have to do with a lack of communication between departments, levels of management, and training teams. This makes more work for this position as we often fill in the blanks. Sometimes even WE are given the wrong information. You deal with Karen's. You must learn to politely tell people no. "No. We cannot do that for you today. Regardless of your logical reasoning for why you should have this option, you do not have that as an option. Thank you. Have a good day." These kinds of conversations make up about 30% of your job so it's not terrible. (Plus we're allowed to tell abusive/threatening customers we will disconnect the call if they don't straighten out.)

review_title: Unfortunately the company has become terrible
pros: Time off is about the only benefit anymore, and it's really dependent on your leader.
cons: PayPal used to be enjoyable and seemed to care about both customers and employees. However, greed and incompetence has led to the exact opposite. Some days I'm not sure how this company is still functioning, let alone succeeding, with the skeleton crew they have left of people that do work. They have extremely inflated executive roles they have filled with people they know that are so unqualified for the position that it's nearly impossible to work with them. They laid off so many people that they didn't replace, followed by droves of people quitting, half the time people are just trying to figure out who does what anymore. Work is constantly left undone, customers are frustrated, and projects are unfunded and stale. This is an absolutely awful environment, unless you obtained one of the high leadership roles simply from nepotism (who doesn't want six figures to do nothing). Raises are 1%, pay is below average, and you have to practically beg to hire necessary help (which takes months to years to fill now). If you can make it until the company is sold or executive leadership is finally gone things may turn around. Otherwise, I would never, ever, ever, ever recommend working here for anyone. The most toxic work environment I have ever experienced and it gets continuously worse day after day. If you enjoy constant anxiety about potentially losing your job and/or you like watching inept people get promoted, that is the only way you will like working here (under this leadership at least).

review_title: Great Company, Great Culture with Lack of Vision, Product & People
pros: PayPal is pioneer in the world of online payments and have been able to build a fantastic network of customers & merchants. The family culture at PayPal promotes inclusiveness. Company offers some fantastic benefits to its employee like RSUs, Insurance, Meal Pass, Work devices including mobile phone etc. The company has fantastic offices across the globe and cares for wellness of employees and thus offers WELLNESS off and Work from Home / Hybrid work model. HR team is supportive and employees were well taken care of during the COVID19 pandemic. There are various learning programs within the company and if you are able to extend your bandwidth to get into one of these, you get to improve your learning curve. PayPal is a paymaster when compared to other Fin-Techs, however this is dependent on the manager. "Organisation is as good as your manager" is very true here.
cons:
Picking up from the last sentence on my Pros list, I was unlucky when it came to Manager. My tenure would have lasted for  >5 years, In-fact i would have loved to continue beyond, little did i know that upon my conversion as a FTE from contract employee i will be told to leave inside 6 months. 

This brings me to my first point lack of vision. Consistent change in senior management, layoffs all throughout the year &  gossip by every single individual present in the organisation then on results in performance depletion from the team/individual & markets. 

Another problem the company lacks product for markets other than their core (US) markets. To the best i understand there has been no innovation to the original innovation and there is no effort to understand their long tail markets and curate products according to the market. 

Coming to People, Its all about I, Me and Myself. You'll rarely come across any person who is a leader and willing to share his/her experience. Survival is the only thing that every person in the sales org is bothered about. since people only bother about survival there is no team bonding infact there is this constant tussle between the sales team of who takes what. When it came to Layoffs the best employees were laid off who really wanted to make a difference and the others who just gossip and fooled the top management survived.

pros:
This is the second review, unfortunately a month after I posted my first review, there was a planned layoff in the company - technology deprecation related (Got nothing to do with the review).

A great company which provides ample opportunities for career growth and overall development. Has good work life balance (not applicable if you are in a screwed up project or if your boss is a workaholic). Great perks, free transport and a beautiful and ergonomic work place. Very good health insurance and life insurance coverage and other support programs. 

HR team is good, for the most part the company actually cares for its employees (some exceptions apply - based on project/boss). Even after I was laid off, the HR team responded well to my queries, they had tie up with another company for transition support.

Nevertheless, even though I was laid off, the company and its culture is still great and if you get a good opportunity, you can definitely join it. But please make sure you keep watching your back !!
cons: Unfortunately, innovation has come down drastically. The stock price crash has triggered disappointment/discontent in some employees. Most of the perks that you get, will be enjoyable only if you are placed in a good project and if your boss is a good guy. review_title: Great benefits, but company is on its way down
pros: PayPal is a typical Bay Area company with great benefits and I believe it is fair to say that the company overall tries to take care of its employees.
cons: PayPal is struggling to find relevance in today's world amidst all the competition emerging. The value proposition was clear years ago when it acted as the middle man between unknown internet merchants and unidentified customers. Today, that is table stakes and the company is plagued with legacy systems that do not allow it to move as fast into new markets and, worse, create a sub-par user experience. Add to that the managements hesitation to explore new opportunities and you have a company that has gone from a leader in FinTech to one that may become irrelevant in a space that it helped pioneer.

review_title: Some good benefits but struggles with poor senior leadership, poor compensation and poor job security
pros:
Coworkers. My direct team and leader are great, smart, caring and wonderful people! 

Good benefits - like sabbaticals, wellness days etc

Ability to work remotely or in the office. 

Meaningful work.
cons:
Low compensation for tasks/performance. The salary for top performers who have worked at PayPal for years is lower than the starting pay for equivalent roles at other companies. No recent cost of living increases to account for inflation. 

Year end performance bonuses are primarily given in the form of RSUs with a 3 year vesting schedule. So you won't see a penny for a year and will lose it if you leave before it vests. 

Poor senior leadership. Frequent re-orgs. No transparency. Executive leadership preaches about core values but their actions directly contradict them. 

Many in senior and executive leadership roles seem under qualified for their position, lack the appropriate knowledge and communicate poorly.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros: the office is near a train station so you can leave fast.
cons:
If you ever dreamed about coming into an office filled with people yet you are invisible- this is the right place for you. 
 Paypal is very clear about CS workers being the bottom of the barrel, all of the decisions that effect our work are made without notice or consideration to us, the communication is lacking to none, zero contact with the rest of the Company and the rest of the departments that effect our day to day work, 
The turnover rate is extreme yet no changes are made since it easier for them to hire new workers then actually make the work bearable, 
If you speak up you will receive a call from HR, and if you can't take the pressure of an understaffed phone line- that's your problem. 
You will not be invited to Company events, yet in the interview they will mention how great those events are, 
You will not be prompted and even if you will- be aware that they can pull you back to your CS job if they need it (understaffed as I said before)
Paypal puts wellness and mental health as a priority, yet customers can scream, curse, and abuse you freely. 
The hierarchy is very clear- you are at the bottom.

pros: Awesome people, interesting projects, constant challenges that drive personal growth and exploration of new ideas and knowledge, solid benefits, I honestly love nearly everything about my day to day job and the culture here with one major exception
cons: Absolutely no room to grow under the current CMO if you’re in an operations role (we shouldn’t sit under marketing but we do, and we’re not valued or respected). I’ve been passed up for multiple promotions to level me up to the job I already do and exceed expectations in for several years now. I’ve stayed because it served a purpose in my life but I’ve hit my limit for the amount of free labor I will provide without level, title, and compensation adjustments. It’s a career growth killer for non-marketers to report into a CMO (especially agile professionals under an anti-agile marketing leadership team).  The structure of the org is detrimental to anyone outside of marketing roles. Time to move on.

review_title: bad place to work if you are ambitious & if you are a good engineer
pros:
1) work-life balance
2) zero work pressure
3) good salary for the amount of work that I did. Although I earned very less compared to my friends in tier-1 companies, for the amount of work that I did, I earned enough.
4) I worked for ~4yrs, and I never had to worry about work. work-life balance is perfect.
cons:
1) Office politics (even who wins a hackathon is decided by office politics)
2) Zero growth in 3years (this depends on your team; my team was very bad)
3) A lot of proprietary software is used. Face a lot of problems during interviews. I was rejected by a lot of startups because of this.
4) Work(in my team at least) is not challenging and also not interesting.
5) Dev environment is very bad. I worked on a project that was supposed to be completed in 1 month, but it took 6months because of unstable Dev environment. Dev testing is really a pain in the ***.
6) Has too many contract workers(AWF). AWFs are very very bad. After giving them the problem, I had to explain the solution in micro detail. Still, they had problems executing it. They ask the same question 1000 times. They don't even google the problem before asking for a solution🤦‍♂️. They depend too much on you and your productivity reduces.
7) All of the challenges in my work were due to bad code, bad dev environment, bad communication between teams.
8) promotion based on your performance is a joke here. You'll get promoted if you are good at politics. I've seen MTS1s writing bad code.
9) some managers do micro-management
10) internal documentation is very bad.

I'm tired I'll add more when I've time...

review_title: Great culture, but terrible senior leadership
pros:
I was part of the overall operations organization structure, but will not specify the department. However, we had geeat culture there and that department was extremely helpful to the entire org. And was very friendly.

The benefits of unlimited vacation really were unlimited vacation and one must take advantage appropriately.

Benefits were great too
cons:
The biggest problem is SALES. I've never worked in a more stressful environment than PayPal for this very reason. I literally had anxiety induced due to the way the sales department is allowed to throw their weight around. I never brought this anxiety issue up, but that is why I left. PayPal, you need to get a massive grip of your sales team, we all need to make momey, but you cannot only focus on making the Sales team the only priority when there are many departments that are working extremely hard as well.

Senior leadership is cold and they're distanced. They don't really listen to employees, and have a very corporate structure that just doesn't work in this day and age. 

Free breakfast, lunch, and dinner was initially provided and was then taken away. Although that's just a perk, it doesn't sit right when perks are taken away and none added.

review_title: Inspiring Vision but Very Political & Slow

Very political - promotions and opportunities are given to the well connected and well known rather than the most qualified.

Extremely slow moving - Company can’t seem to get out of their own way. Poor organizational design and lack of strategy makes it impossible to get anything done. Everyday is a constant struggle to get simple things done. 

Poor leadership and management - Leaders lack expertise in organizational design and strategy so instead spend most of their time micromanaging technical decisions and creating time consuming operational rhythms and unproductive meetings. Makes it impossible to empower SME’s and product teams to innovate. Product and engineering instead spend most of their time catching up with innovative solutions from competitors or tech debt.

review_title: Great company and team that cares about their employees
pros:
Collaborative and supportive environment. Plenty of opportunities to grow if you are willing to seek them out.

Their shared frameworks leave little room for running into dependency issues and time wasting triaging (especially in live) as the paths have mostly been treaded.
cons:
Promotion process can take quite a while even if operating at the same level of output/value. 

The con of having well established framework libraries is there's slightly less room for innovation and experimentation. But dedicated time for hackathons can help bring ideas into the mainstream to explore.

The compensation package is average or at least not better than most FANG companies. You can get a raise coming from a big FANG company moving here etc, but always be willing to negotiate.

job_title: Disputes and Claims Specialist in Dundalk
pros: Work from home and nice colleagues
cons:
Awful conditions of work, literally no time to even go to the toilet. Irrational demands and targets. Insufficient training (which was not even paid in the end!!!). In PayPal you're just a number. They pretend to be very good and fair, however they are the exact opposite. 
They will tell you about those notorious "Flexi days" that you can have. They seemed great in the beginning, until I realised that they don't pay you for your first 2 weeks of training, so, at the end of the day, they try to "compensate" by pretending to be generous, giving you extra free days. Far from free!! Cheery on top: they still owe me more than 1300 € and the Payroll / HR would simply NOT reply to my emails or phones. Managers and team leaders couldn't care less, saying "they have no power over this type of issues", without providing any solution or alternatives. No wonder everyone quits!! I wish I had done so quicker than I did.

review_title: Company with Culture at Heart but lack of vision
pros:
PayPal is pioneer in the world of online payments and have been able to build a fantastic network of customers & merchants. 
The family culture at PayPal promotes inclusiveness. Company offers some fantastic benefits to its employee like RSUs, Insurance, Meal Pass, Work devices including mobile phone etc. The company has fantastic offices across the globe and cares for wellness of employees and thus offers WELLNESS off and Work from Home / Hybrid work model. HR team is supportive and employees were well taken care of during the COVID19 pandemic.
There are various learning programs within the company and if you are able to extend your bandwidth to get into one of these, you get to improve your learning curve.
PayPal is a paymaster when compared to other Fin-Techs, however this is dependent on the manager. "Organization is as good as your manager" is very true here.
cons:
Picking up from the last sentence on my Pros list, I was unlucky when it came to manager. No doubt learning curve under the manager went up in the 5 years tenure however from career perspective things went nowhere. In fact I was on contract for about 4 years of my tenure and got absorbed as a full-time employee in the 5th year at a lower level/compensation as compared to peers. 
Another problem is the short-sighted senior management which changes the strategy in between and multiple re-orgs throughout the year affecting performance of markets / teams / individuals. 
There has been NO innovation since the original innovation of democratising payment. The board also doesn't understand how to WIN local markets and they think One Size (US) fits all.

review_title: An excellent benefit package is the pig's lipstick
job_title: Sr User Experience Designer II in San Jose, CA
pros: Excellent benefits package and big talk on inclusion and accessibility.
cons:
PayPal has an excellent benefits package and possibly the most positive and inclusive work atmosphere of a company I've ever worked for. The 'doer' people are amazing and generally care for one another. Well, at least they were. But unfortunately, over the past six months, PayPal has hemorrhaged that great talent. Perhaps four director-level leaders, a dozen or more manager level, and 30-50 user experience professionals of varying experience, and that's a conservative estimation—all while mandating a hiring freeze and leadership's refusal to promote to fill the open manager positions internally. 

The work is tedious, mind-numbingly simplistic busy work that doesn't live up to the expectations they hyped during the hiring process. Did you like playing with legos growing up? Then, PayPal is perfect for you. They'll tell you to pull creative direct from an obnoxiously rigid component library while being told to 'think outside of the box.' Prepare for a six to seven-step review process more like a firing squad than constructive feedback sessions. If you make it to the Sr Leadership review, be prepared for pushback on how the product should work because the cart-before-the-horse process skipped all UX strategy and planning steps and triads to discuss functionality. Prod tells you exactly what features to build, and btw, there's no wireframe step in this process either; it's straight into designs (see rigid component library). Good luck! 

Speaking of the UX processes, there isn't one. During my first month at PayPal, the Director of UX pulled a hundred or so UXers together to brainstorm process efficiencies. Yet, a year and a half later, leadership didn't implement a single process improvement. 

Management is very condescending and dismissive, and the product team consistently undermines and undervalues the role and importance of UX. (see prod creating features in a silo and presenting to UX.)

You are told from the get-go that things "are always changing," and I think that's true, mainly because no one in leadership knows what the other leaders do. Leadership does NOT actively or meaningfully communicate with each other unless something is broken, and they are NEVER straightforward to their employees or remember what was discussed with them. So be prepared to have 'clear' to-dos coming out of a Friday meeting, only to be questioned about those to-dos the following week as leadership will straight-faced tell you they never mentioned them. 

PayPal brags about being innovative but only promotes the ideas of complacent yes-men they can directly profit from and fails to achieve even basic functionality with its systems most of the time. Every design used is buggy and either half-built or half shut-down (PP canceled three of my products in less than a year. Two before launch.) Tech issues keep people from working for hours at a time, and depending on your geolocation, late-night meetings are a norm (think 11 pm-1 am.) PayPal also has no-meeting Fridays. How great! Unfortunately, few take this company-wide mandate seriously. 

The minute you think for yourself or question management, you are in the wrong. The minute you catch up and get a sense of direction, everything changes arbitrarily and with no notice and little direction/resolution.

PayPal celebrates individuality as long as it helps them save face. PayPal does a lot of excellent PR headlining stunts, but those are only for show.

The only real thing about PayPal is its frustration from its users, and with their secretive, clueless leadership team, that won't ever get better.

PayPal does an excellent job of putting on the facade of the "perfect employer," but in the end, it only cares about lining the pockets of its board members and corporate elite. Our bonus this year... 5-8 shares of stock valued at $70. Literally. Sr Leadership and above however received $. People left in droves. 

Lastly, you'll be underpaid and oversold on "it's all about the stock" as they throw handfuls of the 66% less in value shares your way. Everyone who PayPal hired in early 2021 has seen their shared plummet and is kicking themselves for taking a lower salary on the promise of all that stock. Well, at least I am, and those I was close with shared similar stories. 

A job at PayPal UX might be suitable if you don't want a challenge and are comfortable coasting in your career.

review_title: porque es una  plataforma  bien   yo  que nido la   oputunida de que ne  me dicen es vueno  faci  pa transferir  bien
pros: El dinero es algo muy importante para la mayoría de las personas. Tener un buen manejo de dinero, seguridad de que no se perderá y disponibilidad inmediata es imperativo y por esa razón, progresivamente se han ido creando más opciones para resguardar tu dinero y hacer compras, recibir transferencias o simplemente ahorrar. PayPal es una plataforma en línea fundada en 1998 que se ha dedicado y aún se dedica a procesar pagos desde cualquier parte del mundo; además ha hecho convenios con bancos alrededor del mundo para facilitarles a sus usuarios el retiro de dinero. Muchas personas que deciden empezar un negocio propio, especialmente negocios en línea, deciden utilizar PayPal para agilizar los procesos de pago y para tener absoluta comodidad cuando se trata de dinero.
cons:
Límite de ahorro: Es necesario verificar tu cuenta con una tarjeta de crédito si deseas tener cantidades muy altas de dinero sin tener ningún problema, pues si deseas tener la versión no verificada PayPal, esta plataforma te dará un límite de dinero para tener. Afortunadamente el proceso de verificación es sencillo y rápido.
Comisiones: Dependiendo de dónde vivas, cuánta cantidad de dinero movilices y cuánto tiempo lleves con tu cuenta de PayPal tendrás que pagar comisiones en cada transacción, haciendo que pagues un poco más del precio del producto. No obstante, las comisiones por transferencias internacionales son considerablemente menores a las de un banco.
Disputas: Personas malintencionadas pueden hacer denuncias falsas a PayPal para recuperar el dinero que te han mandado a cambio de un producto o servicio. Por ejemplo, si vendiste una camiseta y ellos dicen que nunca la recibieron, pueden iniciar una disputa contra ti. Esto no significa que te quedarás sin dinero, pero sí puede ser un proceso engorroso; por esa razón, asegúrate siempre de tener pruebas para agilizar estas disputas.
Si eres propietario de un negocio o simplemente una persona que busca tener dinero electrónico, entonces PayPal es una buena opción para ti; además la mayoría de los sitios de internet que sirven para ganar dinero fácil utilizan PayPal como método de pago.

job_title: Data Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
-The nature of my role is that I interface with scores of engineering teams, analysts etc. across PayPal on products that get released all the time. It’s an exciting space to be in
-Visibility is very good, at least in my org
-Unlimited PTO (if you can use it)
-The investopia slack channel
-Focus on gender diversity
cons:
-Reorgs (and rearchitectures depending on the domain) happen nonstop
-Heavy politics. You can tell if you’ve done a project well if three other teams try to take credit for it
-My WLB is dismal. I work 12+ hrs daily. One time I had an ongoing personal emergency (which I notified my team about) and could only work a 40 hour week and I got publicly berated; I was told I needed to “grow up” and work more than 60 hours per week
-Low Pay. We already make less than industry standard, and I recently found out that I’m getting paid 20% less than the rest of my team. Upper management responded by raising my salary 3% 😐
-I have a technical background and I’m in a technical role. However a significant part of my job comes from my boss volunteering to do PowerPoints for their bosses and then farming it out to me
-Be careful who you tell your ideas to. If you show interest in something or if you think something could be more optimized, they will make you do it and own/run it addition to your day job.

job_title: Director, Software Engineering in San Jose, CA
pros: Use the product you build
cons: Large company with many dependent teams

pros: Good culture, decent pay. A variety of positions available.
cons:
I have worked for PayPal for eight years and the first several before we went public were some of the best. We were constantly paid more every year, we got large bonuses and advancement came when you wanted. 

Since going public in 2016 things have been going down hill. Responsibility has skyrocketed and the amount of information you are expected to retain is endless. You need to be a psychologist, a sociologist. You need to be public relations and a product expert in 8 queues. 

PayPal has moved away from specialization in an attempt to break down silos but instead what has happened is PayPal expects more and more work and continues to hand out 2% raises for "Meets Expectations" and rarely hands out "Exceeds" especially if you are on a specialist team. 

In 2019 my pay increased from 35k to 40k which was amazing but every year there after and for a few years leading up to that we were given 2% raises which are consistently below inflation. Which means PayPal would tell me how great I am and then effectively pay me less every year despite increased responsibility. 

I have moved from frontline, to specialists in various roles to senior agent and in that time my pay has moved by a total of 3%. 

This is not acceptable.

review_title: Great company but lacking in long-term strategic vision
pros:
Great environment to work in. The people are caring and there is support to make your working day as great as it can be. The company is flexible in its work ethos and there is a really collegial atmosphere with your workmates.

People work well together and there is surprisingly little egos and politics when compared to some other large companies. 

When it wants to get something done, the business can be focused and deliver quickly and well, but it takes a lot of effort to get there.
cons: Constant re-orgs and job changes means it's hard to focus on your role for long. Feels like there's a very short-term view of strategy, always looking to deliver on what Wall St requirements are for the next quarter rather than take a long-term view of the business. This means your priorities shift regularly and it can feel like you're chasing your tail constantly.

Each re-org has been worse for my team and moral. Less that ethical decisions, illegal retaliation and a very strong management bias when it comes to promotions and layoffs.

pros:
Pros

1. People at PayPal are generally great - very welcoming and friendly and want to work with you to get what you need done

2. Good social values but core company values are only inconsistently followed.

3. Generally (but not always!) good work-life balance and less stressful than other tech companies

4. Good overall benefits package, though not outstanding. I do really like using Schwab for my 401K
cons:
1. Base compensation is poor by industry standards. Raises have been minimal and lag behind inflation. Stock compensation is less enticing when the stock is performing poorly. Management regularly dodges questions about compensation when asked while patting itself on the back for small gains made with the stock. It is not hard to understand why we struggle to keep talent that could be compensated better elsewhere. 

2. Large, sometimes confusing, organization with some teams that are very siloed. Identifying stakeholders and contacts can be difficult. This is not helped by regular reorganizations and constant name changes.

3. Management does not always provide good/strong leadership - reliance on external consultants finding places to make cuts, unclear prospects for growth and a lot of relying on "We will get through this" currently. There is also a major disconnect between management and employees in general and what management says and what the company actually does (in terms of job security, employee compensation, and other things) specifically.

4. Unclear growth potential for many roles, due to limited upward mobility and constant reorganizations. I felt like my only real way to take a step forward is to leave, which is why I went elsewhere.

5. Some areas seem to grasp the high-level obstacles to growth and efficiency without wanting to tackle the underlying issues - they take the easy way of rolling out a high-level policy or just laying people off instead of addressing cultural and other issues that prevent work from getting done.

cons:
Working on Venmo’s side of the corporation, we don’t get all the benefits that ‘actual’ PayPal employees get. Venmo customer service employees are treated very poorly with little to no communication about changes or updates about the company. When you need information, the supervisors don’t know what’s going either so they send you in circles. We don’t have the same time off benefits or shifts as ‘actual’ PayPal employees. They used to preach about opportunities but since being here (4 years) the company has had less and less and now hire outside for more roles.
Now, since working from home, there is a false sense of community and team- what is, is limited and it’s only out there so that the company can check that box.
The turnover is so high that some teammates have gone through 5-8 managers in a single year.

job_title: Director, Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: Above average total compensation packages
cons:
Constant reorgs. I experienced 4 org changes and 6 different leaders in less than 2 years. Each one demanding a new plan and new strategy to be developed in the first weeks they took over. 

Everything is a priority and there is no resourcing to match. You take a job here, it's your 24hr a day 7 day a week commitment because "it's a rocket ship". 7am calls with EMEA, 9pm calls with Asia - it's normal to have 14hour days three or four days a week. 

It's a rocket ship for those with millions in stock, not the lower level employees who do the work. it's just a grind with no end in sight. You get one big project done, and there are three more you are behind on that you get called on the carpet for because that leader is upset his/her project wasn't the first one you did. 

Management runs from one fire to the next. It's all about greasing the squeaky wheels. And the politics are sooooo deep here it's crazy.

There is very little thought to longevity of employees, outwardly the CEO talks about the importance of employees, but internally he is driving programs and demanding outcomes that can't be met by the organization staffing levels. So he is stressing out every department, bursting capacity limits, and demanding more and more every week to satisfy the thirst of investors and drive the stock price up.
